title.narrative: Improving sexual rights of persons with disabilities in Afghanistan Nepal and Tajikistan

description.narrative: Although 15 % of the worlds population live with a disability many of the PwD are marginalized their human rights are violated and their SRHR are not fully recognized. Therefore this project brings together five expert organizations on SRHR and/or disabili ties in Afghanistan Nepal and Tajikistan to realize the sexual rights of PwD so that they can enjoy dignified lives.The project has five mutually supportive outcomes under the themes of capacity building of beneficiaries changing attitudes advocacy capacit y building of SRH service providers and learning. To attain OC1:PwD trainers peer educators and family members are trained and CSOs strengthened; OC2: awareness raising activities are held; OC3): political decision makers capacity is increased; OC4:service providers are trained in disability issues; OC5: best practices to improve SRHR of PwD are identified shared and scaled.Gender equality is an inbuilt component of the project. Addressing the rights of WwD and GwD recognizing the multiple forms of discrimi nation and mainstreaming gender in disability programming are key priorities. The project advocates for structures and services that are inclusive and accessible to WwD. Climate sustainability is ensured by the climate risk management by the POs. The princ ipal premise is reducing discrimination and inequality of PwD; e.g. targeting lack of access to SRH services and societal stigma.The project will be implemented by Vaestoliitto Kynnys MSIA FPAN and Ishtirok. Each partner has strengths and capacity gaps thu s the core approach of the project is learning and sharing to identify new approaches to pilot and adopt. RBM and project management will be strengthened throughout the project. MSIA and FPAN are strong SRHR actors and Ishtiroks strength is their expertise in PwD issues and advancing SRHR of PwD. Kynnys will strengthen the disability expertise and Vaestoliitto the SRHR expertise of all partners.Immediate beneficiaries will be PwD and their families disabled couples individuals and peer educators decision ma kers and government officials sexual health-care providers CSOs and POs in Afghanistan Nepal and Tajikistan.
